email.title: Weekly Digest

image.alt: Stack of biscuits next to tea
image.title: I am eternally offended by a certain first year who suggested that a past digest had a photo of '*coffee* and biscuits'. It's completely absurd to even suggest such a non-traditional combination would appear in a digest email.

email.text:
Hi everyone,
Last week was a busy week, with events including Revel, a Unity workshop, a talk from Palantir, election hustings and finally, our yearly health-related hackathon, Health Hack!
With exam season for third and fourth years, as well as voting opening for the Leadership Elections, we have a quiet week planned ahead so all of us can try focus on some work. If you don't have imminent exams just yet, we do have a talk by an ex-Imperial student (and now-DeepMind employee) next Tuesday and a few other announcements to make. Read on!
email.heading: DoCSoc Merch Collection
email.text: If you ordered merchandise from us this year, they are now on the way and almost ready for collection! We'll be sending out a separate mailshot soon to let you know about collection dates and times.
email.heading: Vote in the Leadership Elections!
email.text:
It's that time of year again where you get endlessly pestered by people asking for you to vote for them. That's right - it's time to vote for next year's DoCSoc committee and wider Imperial College Union roles.
Voting opens tomorrow, Monday 11th March and closes on Thursday 14th March. Be sure to check out candidates' manifestos [here](https://www.imperialcollegeunion.org/your-union/leadership-elections-2019/manifestos/a-to-z) and vote by going to https://vote.union.ic.ac.uk/!
We would also encourage you to vote for CGCU and sabbatical roles too. Sabbatical officers such as the Union President and Deputy President for Finance and Services, as well as CGCU officers such as the President and Treasurer, all affect how well DoCSoc runs.
email.heading: What I Wish I Knew As An Imperial Student (presented by a DeepMind employee)

event.text:
Andrea Michi is an Imperial alumni who's spent the last 3 years working for Google and DeepMind. He'll be coming in to present on everything he would have loved to know before he started his job - a talk which has been very popular when presented internally at Google.
Andrea will cover many soft topics often ignored in the tech industry: how to deal with rejections and failures, what you should prioritise at the start of your career, how to give, receive, and internalise feedback, how you can be a better teammate and a more efficient engineer.

email.heading: Palantir Women in Tech Scholarship
email.sponsor:
We launched the Palantir Women in Technology Scholarship in 2010 to celebrate and support women who are beginning careers in technology. We hope to encourage women to pursue computer science, engineering, and technical studies, and to become leaders in these fields.
This year, 10 scholarship recipients will be chosen and invited to visit our London office for a full-day, all-expenses paid developmental workshop. Programming will include professional development sessions, breakouts with our engineers, and some fun social activities! All recipients are awarded grants of Â£5,500 to support their education.
The scholarship is open to students who:
- Are active, full-time undergraduate or Master's students enrolled in an accredited European college/university during the academic years that the scholarship is awarded, i.e., you must be enrolled in both the current (2018-19) and upcoming (2019-20) academic years - Are majoring in or plan to major in Science, Technology, Engineering or Math (STEM) fields - Identify as women - Have not been finalists in the past
For more information, click [here](https://jobs.lever.co/palantir/2dce1c15-faca-4e91-a8aa-0c2c6a259d77) and see the flyer attached!
